clinical_study.brief_title: Minimally Invasive Surgery (MIS) for Spine Metastases
clinical_study.official_title: Minimally Invasive Surgery for Spine Metastases - A Prospective Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

clinical_study.source: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to collect information on the effect of minimally invasive spine tumor decompression on treated patients. This treatment option is less invasive that the standard surgical decompression and is expected to result in better wound healing, decreased tissue trauma, and decreased pain after surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective study designed to analyze the impact that minimally invasive spine tumor decompression has upon quality of life, neurological morbidity, pain, and mortality. Prospective findings will be compared with historical controls to determine whether the minimally invasive approach offers better outcomes than traditional treatment methods.

secondary_outcome.description: Hauser Ambulation Index to assess mobility by evaluating the time and degree of assistance required to walk 25 feet. Scores range from 0 (asymptomatic and fully active) to 10 (bedridden).
The Cobb angle is used to quantify the magnitude of spinal deformities.

arm_group.description: Those who received minimally invasive surgical procedures
Those who received treatments which include surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.

study_pop.textblock: Chart review of patients having undergone minimally invasive surgery of spine metastases, 18 years and older.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- undergone minimally invasive surgery
- over 18 years of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- unable to give consent
